item.title: Amazon S3 Request Security
item.description: AWS’s request rules and lack of useful customizable limits allow attackers to rack up high bills for S3 bucket owners, including on fully private buckets. The only effective defense is to immediately delete the affected resources when they are targeted. The Problem One of my goals with this site was to create the most functional website possible at the lowest possible cost. And sure, setting up a static site hosting bucket on S3 and forgetting about it seems like a simple solution.

item.title: Hosting
item.description: The site’s CDN is handled by Cloudflare. Free CDN, DNS, optimizations, and added security. Images are hosted using Backblaze B2. Although it doesn’t support many of the features of other cloud storage solutions, it’s a good bit cheaper. More importantly, it allows for the creation of simple request and bandwidth caps that AWS and Google don’t support. I don’t want a small personal site to scale up in case of an attack; I want it to stop loading large assets to minimize the damage.

item.title: Building the Site
